May it please yo
r
good L. where I writte unto
yo
w
last,
e 7 of this moneth, that
e
states
had
resolved to doe somwhat in Britaine, it was a ma-
ter so concluded in their secret assemblie, and not
imparted as yet to
e
Councel of Estate
. For I had
knowledge of their purpose but by meanes of a
frinde. Howbeit
M
r
Barnevelt
by appointement
of
e states came yesterday unto me, and declared
their intention: wherof in their behalf he was wil-
led to request me, to advertise her
Ma
tie
.
For
though they purpose of themselves to send a messenger
unto her, yet their meaning is first, to sounde her
Hig
nes
good liking, by some motion in general, to in-
duce
e Provinces thereby, to allowe
e sooner of their
doing. The effect of their designe was delivered
thus unto me, That forasmuche as the Spaniard
hath taken a strong footing in divers places of Britaine,
w
t
intention, as it seemeth, to possesse
at contrey to
themselves, w
ch
will presently bring
e trafficke, as-
well of
e Englishe nation, as of
e people of these Pro-
vinces, and
e state of bothe contreis into infinit
perils, in that respect they thought it needefull,
at
they should be mightily assailed, both by land and by
sea, and all upon
e soddaine, w
t
out geving them the
leasure to multiplie further, or to fortifie their
places. For good perfourmance wherof they will be
willing for their abilitie to extend it to
e uttermost.
They will arme for their partes 10 or 12 good
shippes, and every shippe of 200 tonnes, w
t
provi-
sion convenient for so many monethes as
e service
shall require. They will also take order for de-
fraieng
e charges of 2000 souldiers, and send 8
or ten Canons, w
t
powder and bullet for 4000 shotte
But all w
t
condition,
at her Ma
tie
will assent, to double
their proportion, or at lest to doe as muche,

and half as muche againe. And likewise of
e
King
they doe require
e furnishing of 2000 horse,
5 or 6 thousand foote, and 8 canons, w
t
a ratable
quantitie of powder and bullet. W
t
this conjun-
ction of common forces, they thinke there is appar
a
ce
to subdue
e Enemie very quickly. But unles her
Ma
tie
and
e King will come to
at proportion, w
ch
they have sette downe, they are wholy out of hope of
doing any good, and they thinke
at
e Provinces
will be moved to doe nothing. For
e place whiche
they desire should be first of all attempted, is
Blavet,
w
ch
they take to be so strong,
at it can not be reco-
vered but by special force: and if
e Spaniardes
be suffered to settle there at will, they can want no
opportunitie to stoppe
e coures of all trafficke, and
still have meanes to be relieved, both w
t
victuals
and souldiers, out of Spaine and from
Dunkerke.
For they say
at Dunkerke is sufficient to send some
thirtie shippes to sea. For
e time of this service
they have assigned it in July, having no c
o
modious
meanes to undertake it any sooner. And for the
raising of those troupes, w
ch
they would imploye,
they rest as yet uncertaine, from whens they maye
drawe them: whether they shall send them from hens,
or take any of those, w
ch
are in
France
already,
or levie some in
England,
if her Ma
tie
be contented.
But howsoever, they will take sufficient order, that
their offer in that behalf shall be perfitly perfourmed
yo
r
L. will vouchesafe to acquaint her Ma
tie
with
their motion, and to signifie w
t
e soonest, for so they
doe intreat, w
at
answear I shall make.
And so I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
